CONSCIOUSNESS,THE BRAIN AND 
WHAT MATTERS’ 

GRANT GILLETT 

1. INTRODUCTION 

When we consider which types of organism have the ethical status 
that we accord to human beings it soon emerges that the presence 
of or capacity for consciousness holds a central role in our thinking. 
Where an individual has not got, or has irrevocably lost, all capacity 
for conscious experience due to brain damage, we cannot see any point 
in keeping that individual alive. A plausible case can and has been 
made that such an individual is no longer a person at all.* However, 
commentators on brain death legislation note that ‘Nowhere do we 
see the terms ‘intellect’, ‘sentience’ or ‘humanness’ which were so 
dear to the earlier whole-brain strategists, ’3 This complaint is clearly 
based on the intuition that moral concern and some capacity for 
consciousness go hand in hand. But what is it to be conscious and 
why does consciousness have this central place in our moral thought? 

A quick response to this question could be given on the basis of 
Nagel’s view that consciousness is a matter of what-it-is-like-to-be this 
or that thing. If there is nothing it is like to be a thing of a certain 
type then our treatment of that thing does not directly matter in a 
way that counts morally.‘ But this does not advance things any 
further apart from catching an intuition about consciousness. In 
particular, this view cannot be regarded as any kind of analysis of 

This paper draws on and in part reproduces arguments about consciousness 
and its neural substrate set out in ‘Consciousness and brain function’,Philosophical 
Psychology, zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA1:3, 1988. Fuller arguments on the basic position are to be found there 
but no hint of the moral implications. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

G .  Gillett, ‘Why let people die?’ Journal zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA.f Medical Ethics, 12, 1986: E.T. 
Bartlett & S. Younger ‘Human death and the destruction of the neocortex’ in Death: 
Bcyond WhoZe-brain crileria (ed R.M. Zaner) Kluwer, 1988, and R. Fletcher, ‘Four 
indicators of humanhood - the enquiry matures’, Hastings Center Report, 4, 1975. 

Bartlett & Youngner, op cit, p.204. 
This allows for indirect dues to unconscious beings. 



182 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGRANT zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGILLETT 

or test for conscious-ness. For instance, a hard-headed technophile 
might claim that there is definitely a what-it-is-like-to-be an Amstrad 
PC although most of us would not agree. But how are we to refute 
him? We could, of course, resort to philosophy by majority and thus 
abandon the analytic tradition or, alternatively, resort to the other 
well-worn (politician’s) technique by reasserting our own view more 
loudly and insistently. Neither of these seems to be a promising path 
toward philosophical enlightenment. 

I will argue that the nature of consciousness and its moral 
significance are related and that a careful conceptual and neurological 
study can yield a powerful insight into why we make certain medical 
decisions in the way that we do. I will begin by outlining the 
neurological and clinical facts that bear on the nature of consciousness. 

2. THE NEUROLOGY OF CONSCIOUSNESS 

When a doctor assesses the consciousness of a patient she normally 
uses a quantitative scale called the Glasgow Coma Scale zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA- GCS. 
She assesses his eye opening, i.e. whether his eyes open spontaneously 
- zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA4, to voice - 3, to pain - 2, or not at all - 1. She also rates 
his motor response which may be appropriate and to command - 
6, a directed response to pain - 5, a semipurposeful response to pain 
- 4, a flexor response - 3, an extensor response - 2, or no response 
at all - 1. She further assesses his verbal ability which may be 
rationdsensible, irrational/conhsed but articulate, incoherent words, 
moaning and groaning, or none at all .  Thus the scale runs from 15 
points to 3 points; the upper reaches are of most help with the present 
problem. 

Consider two patients, A and B: A’s eyes are open, he is answering 
questions in a confused way, and he sometimes does what is asked 
of him, sometimes not (GCS score 13); B is intermittently opening 
his eyes to pain, responding vaguely to painful stimuli, and moaning 
and groaning (GCS score 8). Thus B is not as conscious as A.6 This 
diagnostic distinction is clearly based on the responses that they make 
to certain events and I will argue that a person is conscious in that a 

he can direct his cognitive abilities on any aspect of his environment: 
his concepts or understanding, can, depending on his level of 
conceptual development, engage with anything to which he has 
perceptual access (or, after Gareth Evans - within his egocentric. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

G .  Teasdale & B. ,Jennett, ‘Assessment of Coma and Impaired Consciousness’ , 

Notice that this is an assessment of degree; can we have more or less of 
Loncet, 2:8, 1974. 

what-it-is-like-to-be? 



CONSCIOUSNESS AND THE BRAIN zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA183 

space).’ His responsive activity reveals the ways in which he can 
extract information from what is before him and appreciate its qualities zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
- colour, warmth, softness, movement, sounds, friendliness and zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAso 
on. A conscious person can think about what is happening to her and 
form her thoughts into a growing appreciation of herself and her 
present situation. This implies that she can ‘tell’ what it is she is 
perceiving. ‘Tell’ is, of course, ambiguous in a revealing way in that 
it can indicate either that the subject knows what is happening or that 
she can report on her experiences. That there is a relationship between 
these uses is evident from the fact that a thinker’s verbal reports are 
just a subset of the range of behaviours which show her responsiveness 
to what is around her. The position I will favour claims that 
consciousness paradigmatically or essentially is a matter of the capacity 
for directed and flexible sensitivity toward the environment. It implies 
that consciousness involves abilities which are also central in the grasp 
of concepts and therefore elucidates the link with language.’ In fact 
this paradigmatic link is zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAdc zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAfatto ablated in a certain type of neurological 
disorder. 

In clinical practice we can define a set of cases, based on the criteria 
used in the assessment of coma, where it is quite clear that 
consciousness is no longer present and thus that the patient has lost 
important capacities central in our moral attitudes toward persons. 

Most of what makes a person a distinct individual is lost when a 
person is unconscious, especially if he or she will always remain 
so. Personality, memoy, purposive action, social interaction, 
sentience, thought and even emotional states are gone. Only 
vegetative functions and reflexes persist. If food is supplied, the 
digestive system functions and uncontrolled evacuation occurs; the 
kidneys produce urine; the heart, lungs and blood vessels continue 
to move air and blood; and nutrients’are distributed in the body. 

Exceedingly careful neurological examination is essential in order 
for a diagnosis of complete unconsciousness to be made. Application 
of noxious stimuli to the nerve endings of an unconscious patient 
leads to simple, unregulated reflex responses at both the spinal and 
brain stem levels. Reflexes may allow some movement, grimacing, 
swallowing and pupillary adjustment to light. If the reticular 
activating system of the brain stem is intact, the eyes can open and 
close in regular daily cycles. The reflex activity can be unsettling 
to family and other observers, but the components of behaviour

* This is discussed in some detail in ‘The generality’constraint and conscious 

thought’ An~lyziz, 47, 1987, pp. 20-4. 



184 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGRANT GILLETT 

that produce this appearance are ‘accompanied by an apparent total 
lack of cognitive function’. In order to have awareness a person 
must have an integrated functioning of the brain stem’s activating 
system with the higher ‘thinking’ functions from the thalamus and 
cerebral hemispheres. Many patients whose brain dysfunctions 
cause unconsciousness nevertheless have fairly intact brain stem 
and, if provided extensive nursing care, are able to remain alive 
without respirator support for many years.g zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

We call the state described here the ‘persistent vegetative state’ (PVS) 
for obvious reasons. But notice that there are undefended moves in 
this passage from the ‘apparent total lack of cognitive function’ to 
unconciousness. This is precisely where we need a careful defence 
because we do not want to abandon our moral concern for a patient 
who would perhaps be able to enjoy a series of pleasant dreams. That 
worry is generated by the view equating consciousness to an inner 
state uniquely accessible to the subject herself in which she ‘enjoys’ 
certain experiences. This view severs any conceptual link between 
mental states and manifestation. lo 

An initial move against this worry involves an inductive argument 
based on the correlation between mental ascriptions and brain 
functions; however this move relies on a conceptual argument to secure 
the conclusion. 

Metabolic data from coma patients are very revealing. Using a 
technique called Positron Emission Tomography (PET), we can 
monitor glucose utilisation by different regions of the cerebrum and 
this gives us a clear indication of whether or not those areas are 
functioning. Such studies demonstrate that a vast amount of higher 
processing is defunct in those patients in the persistent vegetative state 
(PVS). 

These PET results demonstrate a profound reduction of cerebral 
glucose metabolism in vegetative patients. The changes inolved not 
only the cerebral cortex but also the basal nuclei and the cerebellum, 
with which these higher centres normally interact. Furthermore 
no metabolic overlap occurred between either normals or persons 
who were locked in.” 

‘Deciding to Forego Life-Sustaining Treatment’ President’s Commission: U.S. 
Govt Printing Office, 1983, pp. 174-5. 

This immediately should raise questions for those who follow Davidson, 
McDowell or Peacocke or any who, as I am, are in a broadly Wittgensteinian 
tradition. Each of these strands of philosophy takes the question of conditions for 
mental content ascriptions quite seriously.

in vegetative vs locked-in-patients’, Annals zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAof Neurology, 22, 1987, pp. 673-82.

The ‘locked in syndrome’ is a condition in which the patient is awake 
but cannot move anything or speak. She usually communicates by 
rolling her eyes. Locked in syndrome is most often caused by a small 
vascular lesion in the ventral pons or midbrain and 60% -80% of 
patients never recover. (Those who do recover often have revealing 
tales to tell about what was said and done in their presence.) 

There are also differences between PVS and sleep. 

The clinically diagnosed vegetative state was accompanied in this 
study by profound cerebral metabolic depression, with no overlap 
in cortical gray rCMRGlu [regional Cerebral Metabolic Rate for 
Glucose] between vegetatives and normals. The mean cortical 
rCMRGlu reduction of zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA60% in our vegetative patients far exceeds 
the 13 % decline reported in non dreaming sleep in normal persons 
. . . When taken together with clinical evidence of chronicity, the zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
50-60% reduction in metabolic rate found in vegetative patients 
offers strong evidence that such bodies can no longer either think 
or experience pain and suffering. l2  

The metabolic facts true of sleep in general apply zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAafortiori to dreaming 
in which the cortex is more metabolically active than in any other 
phase of sleep. In fact the dreaming brain is remarkably similar in 
its electrical activity to the waking brain. But again we should note 
that these medical authors, in discussing the mental ascriptions 
involved, leave the crucial meanings of the words ‘think or experience 
pain and suffering’ undefined. Thus we still lack an analysis that allows 
us to make confident claims about consciousness and ethical value 
based on brain function criteria. Lest this is thought to be an idle 
query I must report that the most constant question asked in ethical 
presentations of patients with PVS is ‘HOW do you know that they 
are not still conscious ‘in there somewhere”?’. To answer this query 
(which is merely an unsophisticated and particular version of more 
general worries about verificationism) we need an excursion into 
mental philosophy. It is clear that versions of this worry could fuel 
a rational sanctity-of-life view regarding irreversible brain-damaged 
patients and could sway medical care-givers into giving life-saving 
treatment to such patients. The present philosophical arguments are 
therefore of practical interest both to clinicians and economists 
responsible for resource allocation. l 3  

Ibid, [parentheses are mine] 
There are a large number of PVS patients kept alive in the USA and some 

in Britain all of whom cost a vast amount to maintain in their permanently comatose 
con on. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA13

186 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGRANT GILLETT 

3. A PHILOSOPHICAL UNDERSTANDING OF 
CONSCIOUSNESS 

Although consciousness is widely referred to in medical ethics and 
philosophical arguments and is regarded as the key to understanding 
what is special about mental states, it is difficult to find a clear account 
of what it is. Wilkes reminds us of our damaging lack of intuitive 
unanimity about consciousness. This, as I have noted, is fatal for any 
who want to place any weight on an unadorned what-it-is-like-to-be 
view. 

Nobody, I assume, would wish to argue that ‘conscious’ or its 
nominalisation ‘consciousness’ are clear notions. The range of 
disagreement about the scope of the terms puts that out of the 
question zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA- on the one hand we find those liberally expecting to 
ascribe consciousness one day to computers, taking it for granted 
that human and many infrahuman animals are indubitably 
conscious; while on the other hand we find those like Sir John Eccles, 
or Descartes, who do or might deny consciousness to artefacts, to 
the right hemisphere of the human brain, and to non-human 
animals. 

In these remarks Wilkes strikes at many extant theories and beliefs 
about consciousness but her attack is particularly damaging to the 
Cartesian conception of consciousness. This (widely held) view of 
‘consciousness’ - as a term denoting an inner state clear to 
introspection but not otherwise-implies that in the case of another 
person I infer that he is conscious from outer signs and thus can only 
determine whether he is or not in an indirect way. Thus it sets the 
stage for recurrent questions such as the one about PVS. But the 
Cartesian view requires careful scivtiny and the obvious method to 
use is to unpack what we mean by saying that X is consci~us.’~ 

There are two different uses of the term ‘conscious’. One can be 
conscious zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAsimpliciter or conscious of something or other. In everyday 
life we must be conscious (simpliciter) in order to be conscious of things 
about us or even of our own states of mind. However we have to dig 
a little deeper than this to decide which is conceptually prior. 

Wittgenstein remarked ‘Consciousness is as clear in his face and 
behaviour as it is in myself‘. This remark runs directly counter to 
the prevailing view. Consciousness is surely a state of mind and as 

*’ zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAK.V. Wilkes, ‘Is consciousness important?’ in Brit. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAJ. Phil. Sci., 35, 1984, pp. 
223-243. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

Is This does not entail that we spell out necessary and sufficient conditions for 
the application of ‘conscious’ (we cannot do this for many of the terms we use), but 
that we try to characterise the content of that term as used in natural language. 



CONSCIOUSNESS AND THE BRAIN 187 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
such must be ‘internal’. Our intuition is that such states just zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAUYG far 
more clear in one’s own case than they are in the case of others, and 
that this is a general and essential feature of states of mind. So, what 
possible view of consciousness leads Wittgenstein to say what he does? 
The answer emerges from his theory of meaning. 

States of mind are like other subjects of discourse. We describe 
ourselves as being in them and so forth in terms which are essentially 
communicable. But it is essential to communication that the words 
that we use to express ourselves have a (relatively) fixed meaning when 
used by different speakers. Frege clearly saw that any other hypothesis 
would undermine any substantive notion of truth or knowledge (in 
fact it would arguably undermine the nature of meaning tout court). l6 

But this implies that when I use a word, it should be possible for you 
to know what I mean. What is more, if there is a link between meaning 
and truth, you and I should judge my remarks to be true in exactly 
the same circumstances (apart from explicable disagreement). 
Now, clearly that could not be the case if what I meant was a matter 
of being in an inner state to which you could have no access and of 
which you could have no knowledge. An example makes this clear. 
If I say ‘I am glok’ and you ask me what I mean by ‘glok’, it does 
not help for me to say ‘Well, being glok is just something inside of 
me which you can never know about’. Unless ‘glok’ has some outward 
significance or role in my behaviour then it must remain a meaningless 
term as far as communication between us is concerned.” But 
consciousness is clearly not that way and therefore, whatever 
consciousness is, it is something we can recognise in each other. 

If consciousness is something that we can all discuss and if we can 
have meaningful disputes as to what it is we are talking about, then 
there must be ways of telling (in a sufficient number of cases to establish 
the intersubjective meaning of ‘conscious’) whether another person 
is conscious. We must zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAall converge at least in most of our judgements 
that so and so is or is not conscious and, in fact, we do: It is possible 
for neurological specialists to know when consciousness is absent.Ig 
Of course, some cases do not neatly fall on one side or another of 
the hallowed divide between conscious and unconscious. But the things zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

188 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGRANT GILLETT 

about another person that I register when I judge that he.is or is not 
conscious can only be things like what he attends to, how he reacts 
to what is around him and the nature of his responses to, interactions 
with or actions upon things he encounters. These things make it true 
for me to say that somebody is conscious. Now, if we are to mean 
the same by our words, then what makes it true for me to say a person 
is conscious cannot be different from what makes it true for him to 
say that he is conscious. This is because, as Frege so clearly pointed 
out, there would be no point in human knowledge unless truth at least 
was shared and objective. But this implies that the publically accessible 
things which make it true or not to say that someone is conscious also 
determine in part the meaning of the word ‘conscious’. To be conscious 
is therefore to be attentive to, perhaps responsive to and thus able 
to act upon (assuming no motor impediment) things around one. Of 
course, these responses etc. are zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAto things and thus involve what 
Brentano and others have called the ‘intentionality’ or object- 
directedness of consciousness. Thus I would suggest that being 
‘conscious7 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA(simpliciter) is a concept built upon the many acts of being 
‘conscious of‘ one’s environment. 

The argument to date is relatively simple. 

(i) The inner state view of consciousness captured by the phrase 
what-it-is-like-to-be rests on indefensible and unshared intuitions. 

(ii) This view provides no way of resolving conflicts of intuition about 
the range of creatures who satisfy the concept (conscious). 

(iii) But consciousness does have a clear range of applications to those 
who understand the concept. 

(iv) This entails that there is widespread agreement about whether 
a is conscious for a sufficient range of a’s. 

(v) Such agreement in judgements rests on public criteria. 
(vi) Therefore consciousness involves manifest and complex 

sensitivities to things around a subject. 
(vii) The consciousness (simpliciter) is conceptually dependent on a 

multiplicity of abilities to be conscious of this or that.20 

The essential intentionality of consciousness (the fact that it involves 
sensitivity to things around a creature) also introduces another feature 
of consciousness. Human thought is both structured and flexible. It 
provides a structure of categories or concepts which link different 
experiences and potential experiences and also a repertoire of responses 
that a person can use in a flexible way to serve any of the wide diversity 

As is typical of an argument that seeks to elucidate the meaning of a key term, 
this argument resists the naive formalism that often obscures fundamental 
philosophical problems. 



CONSCIOUSNESS AND THE BRAIN 189 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
of purposes she might conceive for herself in a particular situation. 
Humans can and do selectively attend to different aspects of a situation 
and detect the same conceptual feature in a series of different situations. 
Consider the example of a child responding to a row of coloured 
shapes. We ask her to pick out a red one. To  do this she must attend 
to the colours of the shapes and pick from them the red one, ignoring 
its shape or position or size. If we asked her to pick out a square or 
a circle then she would have to attend to and select from the array 
in quite a different way. Such perceptual selectivity becomes part of 
and is elaborated by the human ability to use a meaningful term or 
concept to pick out one feature from what one confronts or to orient 
one’s activity in the world in a particular way. The term, we could 
say, marks and ‘catalyses’ the ability or technique intrinsic to the grasp 
of a concept. As the child learns of discriminations to be made she 
refines the selective abilities needed to make them. She learns of such 
possibilities by noting the differences marked by the signs that other 
people use. Thus language (or being able to tell) is entwined with 
what it is to beconscious in a fully human way. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
4. CONSCIOUSNESS AND THE STRUCTURE OF THOUGHT 

We can relate this internal connection between mental abilities and 
signs to the structured nature of conscious thought. The structure in 
thought is what allows us to make inferences and connections between 
the judgements we make about different experiences.“ An inference 
is, after all, a connection between facts that extracts further information 
from what we already know. For instance, the judgement ‘That is 
a cat’ may connect a present experience with a number of others in 
which four-legged creatures chased mice. This judgement therefore 
allows the inference ‘It is possible that this animal will chase that 
mouse’. Thus human thought is zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAarticulated in the sense that it enables 
to identify certain features relevant for action on the basis of 
connections between one’s experiences. Human thought enables 
experience to be structured in a multiplicity of ways marked by terms 
linked to what one has encountered before and found to be significant 
or useful. 

Concepts, and their relation to language, make these connections 
clear. Think of a concept like (blue). Grasping the meanings of ‘That zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

*’ Wittgenstein notes this in Philosophical Remarks (see below) and in Blue and 
Brown Books, (Oxford: Blackwell), pp. 4-6. Gareth Evans introduces the structured 
nature of conscious thought in Varieties ofRefcTence (Oxford: 0 . U . P  1981, pp. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA1OOff); 
I have discussed his view in ‘The generality constraint and conscious thought’, 
Analysis, 47, pp. 20-24. 



190 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGRANT GILLETT 

is blue’, ‘The dog is blue’, I saw a blue flower in her garden’ and 
so on involves appreciating that they have something in common 
expressed by the term ‘blue’. One develops the ability to identify blue 
things by linking these experiences and thus learns zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAto appreciate 
something which is missed by those who do not have that concept. 
It is clear that such an appreciation extends our consciousness of each 
individual experience. Thus we can further refine our view of 
consciousness: to be conscious zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA(simpliciter) is to be in a state in which 
one can use an articulated repertoire of exploratory and action-guiding 
abilities to respond to many different things of which one can be 
‘conscious’ (transitive). 

Wittgenstein makes a contrast between human responses which 
illuminates the nature of conscious thought.22 Whereas a reflex like 
salivation is.a limited response rigidly linked to a specifiable trigger, 
a thought is an exploratory and unifying tool. It is useful precisely 
because it ranges over a wide range of situations and links experiences 
which may have no obvious connection with each other. It does this 
by framing them against a system of concepts which is finely crafted 
to detect and exploit the aspects of experience that are relevant to 
the current purposes of the concept user. What is more there is no 
simple link between a thought and behaviour, rather the thought is 
part of a structure which can be used to form and inform an indefinite 
number of different responses to situations. 

For our present purposes, we can conclude that the interplay of 
directed gaze, investigative activity and response marks a being as 
conscious zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAand underpins the *complexity of thought. These 
manifestations would also form the zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAcriteria of consciousness in that some 
subset of them grounds any ascription of consciousness to a subject. 
They show where attention is being directed and thus evince the 
abilities at the heart of ascriptions which involve content such as ‘he 
is looking at his mother’, ‘he sees the flash’ or ‘he is aware that we 
are here’. In fact, such abilities to correlate a wide range of stimulus 
arrays and analyze them according to different plans and projects 
(characteristic of conscious versus reflex activity) are central in any 
articulated system of  concept^.'^ Human thought in particular is thus 
seen to be at least as rich, flexible, generalizable and potentially abstract 
as is human language. 

22 Philosophical Remarks, Oxford: Blackwell, 32. 
23 Although such a repertoire is apt for expression in language it is obviously 

developed along with linguistic ability rather than being secondary to it. Words 
strengthen ability rather than being secondary to it. Words strengthen and mark 
the selective abilities one has and the meaning of those words draws from the complex 
activity in which they are used. (This I would take to be Wittgenstein’s picture of 
meaning and understanding.) 



CONSCIOUSNESS AND THE BRAIN 191 

5. THE EPISTEMOLOGY OF DIFFICULT CASES zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
We now have a philosophical grip on the worry that consciousness 
might lurk undisclosed in a person in PVS. I have argued that 
consciousness is essentially (i.e. in its nature) the capacity to exercise 
a number of manifest sensitivities which in some cases may be 
~oncealed.‘~ Thus consciousness is developed upon zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA(defucto or as a 
matter ofgenesis) and predicated upon zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA(upion’ or as a matter of essmce) 
engagement with things around us.25 Because manifestation is 
criterial for ascriptions of consciousness, we can conclude that the PVS 
patient is not presently conscious. An ‘inner-state’ view rests 
ascriptions of consciousness on ‘symptoms’ by analogy with one’s own 
case and must, therefore, make an inference from behaviour or from 
brain damage via a metaphysically suspect identity theory. These views 
are hampered because in the ‘locked-in’ syndrome we have a 
disconnection between consciousness and behaviour. Such views must 
therefore rest on an inductive claim about the empirical correlations 
between brain states and consciousness but they usually fail to detail 
this claim because of the epistemic problems with which they are beset. 
They are welcome to the correlation I am about to provide but will 
find that it has a sting in the tail for the unadorned intuitive view 
I have found reason to reject. 

Note that we cannot claim philosophical support from the present 
approach for a claim that conscsiousness is absent in the ‘locked in’ 
case because we know that manifestation is impossible in such a case. 
Where manifestation has zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAde fucto been disconnected from cognition 
by some event then the epistemic position is different both from the 
normal situation and from that where the substrate of articulated, 
interest-directed cognition has been destroyed (as in PVS); we can 
therefore make no confident pronouncements. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA26 

The present view also has fruitful implications for a substantial 
notion of self-consciousness, by which I mean the monitoring of mental 
function said to be characteristic of persons. Just as consciousness 
involves engagement with the environment in a range of 
interconnected ways which depend upon a system of concepts being zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

24 This detaches essence from necessary and sufficient conditions and links it to 
what Wittgenstein would call ‘criteria’. 

25 This has obvious links to Brentano’s claim that conscious activity is 
intentional. 

26 The philosophical justification for the relevance of natural states of affairs can 
be gleaned from David Lewis’ frequent invocation of ‘this and nearby worlds’, or 
from the excellent artice by G.  Seddon ‘Logical possibility’, Mind, 31, pp. 481-94. 
I have discussed it in ‘Reasoning about persons’ in Persons and Personality, (ed. A.R. 
Peacocke zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA& G. Gillett), Oxford: Blackwell, 1987. 



192 GRANT GILLETT zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
in play, so self-consciousness has the same basis. The appreciation 
of one’s experiences requires a widespread articulation of the contents 
of those experiences by different conceptual capacities. These include, zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
inter uliu, the capacities that formulate motivations into a system of 
reasons. What is more, the fact that judgements involved in applying 
concepts to the contents of experience are rule governed entails that 
one can assess the propriety of those judgements one has made. When 
such evaluation is combined with a system of reasoning it amounts 
to reflection on experience conducted in the light of what matters to 
(has motivational force for) the subject. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA*’ It is plausible that such 
evaluative reflection is based on the reactions of others to the responses 
one makes when one is learning concepts.28 By this means the 
subject is not only given a model for her responses to the world but 
also for judgements about her own responses. In making these latter 
judgements she articulates her responses within zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAan extensive repertoire 
of cognitive abilities. In judging her responses she learns what counts 
as, say, anger just as in judging things that confront her she learns 
what counts as, say, a dog. The concepts she applies to herself in this 
way are derived from ascriptions made by others which both form 
and then clarify her mental activity. When she can make such self- 
ascriptions she has what we call self-consciousness and could be said 
to be monitoring her own behaviour. 

6. CONSCIOUSNESS AND CEREBRAL FUNCTION 

We can link this analysis of consciousness and self consciousness to 
the relevant neuropsychology so as to provide an empirical application 
for the conclusions I have reached. 

A rudimentary acquaintance with neuroscience should now suggest 
why the cortex and cortical function is an essential part of all conscious 
appreciation and activity. Cortical function is both potentiated by 
ascending activity from the brain stem reticular formation (BRSF) 
and non-specific thalamic projection system (NSTS) and also 
dependent upon stimulus correlations and loadings mediated by the 
limbic system and lower brain. It is the cortex that allows the 
correlative and selective information processing that enables human 
beings and higher animals to structure their reactions to and activity 
in the world in the way that is characteristic of conscious thought. 
The type of attentional selectivity and information linkage between 
one array and another which constitutes, on my account, conscious 

27 On this see J. Church, ‘Reasonable irrationality’, Mind, XCVI, 1987, pp. 
354-66. 

Sec R. Hard, ‘Persons and selves’ in Persons and Personality, op cit. 



CONSCIOUSNESS AND THE BRAIN 193 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
appreciation requires both detailed analysis of stimulus arrays and 
the ability to selectively enhance the information access of certain 
inputs because of their significance to the organism. These two 
components of conscious awareness parallel the function of cortical 
and subcortical centres (although the two dynamically interact). 

The cortex, as we have noted, is a vast array of information 
processing units in which columns of cells produce a range of responses zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
to aspects of stimuli presented to the organism. The responses of these 
units depend on their own state of activation and co-occurrent activity 
in other columns and connected areas of the brain. In fact the state 
of activity in any given column is a joint function of the excitation 
patterns coming into it from projection neurones which I will crudely 
assign to two groups, specific and non-specific. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA. 

Specific input comes from two sources: 

topographically organised relays such as those in the brain stem, 
thalamus or basal ganglia; and 
cortico-cortical projections from other units or arrays of cells 
which, for their own part, have preferential response 
characteristics to various stimulus patterns. 

Non-specific input is a function of (a) the general arousal value 
of the stimulus relayed via the BSRF and NSTS and (b) orienting 
responses which probably arise from limbic structures. Therefore 
both the specific and non-specific systems function in conscious 
activity. The cortex must be alerted to the fact that there is 
something important to be responded to and the subcortical 
systems must then ensure that the cortex serves up a specification 
which tallies with the vague specification that they have of the 
item of interest. This then allows tracking of that item with the 
aid of detailed cortical processing for as long as the requisite 
cortical processing for as long as the requisite cortical sytems 
can be kept in an appropriately active and focused state. Should 
action be required, a plan of action would be generated from 
the cortex and executed by the sub-cortical motor systems. There 
is good evidence that the limbic system plays a vital role both 
in the initial orienting responses to a situation and in the 
motivationally based direction of cortical processing. 

The preferred patterns of excitation for brain cells are, in part, a 
function of genetically determined processing structure and in part 
a result of learned patterns of co-occurrence and salience in terms 
of goal states or cues. Parallel Distributed Processing (PDP) networks 
have shown us how both co-occurrence of input features and the 
presence of collateral inputs (perhaps motivational or ‘teaching’ cues 



194 GRANT GILLETT 

in an ecological field) can be important in generating preferential 
patterns even in an undifferentiated neural ne t~ork .~ ’  The animal 
brain does not, of course, start with an undifferentiated zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAtubulu rasu 
but with species-specific predispositions to react in certain ways.30 
Thus the human brain is set to respond in learnedhocially interactive 
terms to situations by weighing both incoming information and 
occurrent motivation. This allows inputs to be mapped on to the 
conceptual structure of the organism (doxastic and orectic). 

We can now ask questions about the necessity for conscious function 
to be realised in activity involving the cortex. If it emerges that cortical 
function is a sim zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAqua zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAnon of conscious activity in humans then we would 
possess a good inductive argument for considering the PVS patient 
not only as being comatose but as being irreversibly comatose. 

The highly articulated informational capabilities of the cortex are 
exactly what our analysis would suggest as the neural substrate of 
conscious thought. The flexibility and structure of conscious thought 
and the role of selective concept-guided attention and action zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAare exactly 
the type of functions that the complex topographic organisation of 
the cortex is admirably suited to serve. Such organisation enables 
common and similar elements and patterns within a given range of 
experiences to be detected or related in ways relevant to an organism’s 
current activity. Only this kind of processing capacity will enable 
conscious conceptual thought and only conceptual appreciation of what 
confronts one enables the richness of human response and reaction 
that are what we refer to when we talk of something as fully conscious. zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
7.  HUMAN PARADIGMS AND INFRAHUMAN THOUGHT 

This discussion has placed great emphasis on human thought, but has 
implications for animal consciousness. Consider a hedgehog heading 
toward the hedge. Here we might be inclined to say that it is aiming 
to reach the hedge. But we do not know what content the hedgehog’s 
experience has - we do not know whether it recognises the hedge 
as a fuchsia hedge, or even as a hedge, bush or patch of foliage, rather 
than just a place to hide. At the extreme we might conclude that the 
hedgehog’s behaviour is just a taxis, as it would be were it to be the 
behaviour of an ea r th~orm.~’  

29 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAI have discussed this in ‘Representations and cognitive science’ zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAZnquity, 
forthcoming, 1989. ’’ Evidence of this in humans is seen in the natural tendency toward congruence 
and complementarity of responses between infants and their care-givers and is zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA
discussed in both ‘Concepts, structures and meanings’ Znquiv, 101-12, and ‘Learning 
to erceive’ Philosophy and PhenommolOg.iCa1 Research, XLVIII, 1988, pp. 601 -18. 

A zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAtaxis is just a reflexive tendency for an organism to respond to some quality 
like light, gravity or warmth. 



CONSCIOUSNESS AND THE BRAIN 195 

It is clear that, to some extent and in a way which is difficult to 
characterise zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA, many animals are conscious of things and therefore can 
be interpreted as having an appreciation of experience which shares 
certain features with human mental life.32 On that basis, given the 
role of motivation in the structure of thought we could say that the 
animal’s experience matters in somewhat the same way as it would 
matter to a person. But for us to conclude that things did matter to 
an animal it would need to evince zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAa certain complexity and 
purposiveness in its behaviour. 

It should, however, be evident that the central or paradigmatic use 
of the term ‘conscious’ is in relation to human experience. In the 
human case we know what we mean when we say that an individual 
is conscious of this or that. Such judgements provide us with the terms 
in which we then attempt to understand the thoughts and feelings 
of animals (what-it-is-like-to-be-a-bat for instance).33 But these terms 
do not carry over from human experience to the animal cases without 
loss of content. What is clear is that in their central (i.e. human) use 
being conscious and actively detecting and responding to the features 
of the world that surround one is a capacity in which a crucial role 
is played by the neocortex. It is also a capacity which, in virtue of 
the way it links our experiences, enables reason-guided action. There 
is thus an essential link between consciousness and reason (on any 
tolerably broad-minded view of reason). It remains to outline the 
pivotal link (for ethics) between reason and what matters to an 
individual. 

Before we forge that €ink we can review progress to date. I have 
argued that it is the complex of related capacities characteristic of 
consciousness that distinguish persons and that underwrite our 
inclination to view humans as a distinct class of individuals to whom 
we must take certain moral attitudes. I have discussed the link between 
persons and moral dues elsewhere and in other termsg4 but the 
present purpose is to clarify the connection between awareness or 
consciousness of the paradigmatically human type and moral value; 
the findings zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAcan then be applied to modes of being zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAsuch as PVS . Recall 
that PVS patients are not only presently unconscious but have 
sustained brain damage which amounts to a loss of the neural substrate 
of consciousness. 

” zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBANotice that this loosens mental ascription from the dose link to verbal 
behaviour that Davidson, for instance, would favour. 

” T. Nagel in zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAMortal zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAQuestions, Cambridge: C.U.P. We must, of course, notice 
that there are aspects to bat experience (e.g. sonar) that are totally dissimilar to 
anything about our own. 
” ‘Why let people d i e ? ’ J o d  of Medical Ethics, op. cit. 



196 GRANT zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGILLETT 

8. MORAL JUDGEMENTS, CONSCIOUSNESS AND 
CORTICAL FUNCTION, 

Whatever else qualifies a set of judgements as moral judgements, they 
concern what matters to oneself and others. A creature to whom 
nothing matters, nor ever will, cannot be harmed in the way that is 
central in morality (setting aside for the moment questions about 
husbandry and conservation). But what constitutes ‘mattering’ to an 
individual? It is clear that a purely reflexive response to a stimulus 
does not entail that the stimulus matters to the organism in more than 
a highly attenuated and metaphorical sense. This can be shown by 
considering an earthworm. We could say that the descent of a 
particular spade mattered a great deal to a particular earthworm but 
we would not mean by that to imply that the earthworm cared about 
or had an attitude toward the spade descending on it. In this and 
related instances any attitude ascribed to the earthworm is totally 
projected from what-it-would-be-like-to-be-us (as one to whom things 
do matter) in the earthworm’s predicament. The earthworm just goes 
on reacting in a reflexive, survival-enhancing way until it is stopped 
from doing so, it does not have attitudes to anything. It does not have 
attitudes and indeed cannot because it has not got the machinery to 
enable conceptual thought, consciousness, or reasoning about what 
happens to it (which, I have argued, are all intimately and essentially 
connected). Thus, although we cannot condone wanton destruction 
of any life form, we cannot really get morally concerned about things 
that matter to particular earthworms because things just do not matter 
to them. 

In order for something to matter to an individual, he must have 
or be able to form an attitude or preference about that thing zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA- it 
must figure in his thought in some salient or significant way. That 
is what it is to care about something. A thing that I care about is 
connected to certain of my experiences in ways which invoke conative 
associations to thoughts that I might have about it. A creature without 
conscious thoughts does not care about what is happening to it in this 
way. For similar reasons, I cannot care about a momentary event 
on the fleeting screen of experience unless it engages or becomes 
articulated with my thoughts in some ramifying way. Only thus does 
it assume a meaning for me. Once it has done that, I can reason about 
it and incorporate it into my choices, expectations, plans and projects. 
The conceptual and conative ramifications that it has thus specify how 
and why something matters to me. These features are, of course, 
constructed from the concepts through which we and other humans 
(and the animals of whom we are able to make a certain amount of 
sense) understand the events in our lives. Many things become fitted 



CONSCIOUSNESS AND zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBATHE BRAIN 197 

into our mental lives by being integrated with each other through this 
system of concepts, and it is only by so doing that they figure in our 
reasoning. Thus a large, indeed potentially infinite, number of events 
matter in some way or another to us. Of course if there is no way 
in which they matter nor any reason why they matter to us then they 
just do zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAnot matter to us zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA(suns phrase). 

However, to say that they do not matter to any subject is not to 
say that they do not matter in any sense. To make that move we would 
have to argue that only things that matter (occurrently) to some 
individual matter at all. It may well be that things do matter which 
do not matter to the individual they immediately affect. Clearly other 
moral values apart from what matters to an individual who is the object 
of an action may (arguably) bear upon the way in which that action 
matters morally. 

There is one further qualification in this area. It may be that I am 
temporarily in a state where certain events are not engaged with my 
thought processes and yet those events do matter to me in virtue of 
the role they will have in my thought at some other time. In this case 
I could be said to have default interests in those things. They would 
be held to matter to me because of the role they are suited to fill in 
the structure of my thought rather than that which they actually do 
or do not fill at present.35 

The articulation zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAor connectedness which lies at the base of 
conceptual thought and thus reasoning is a feature of experience 
enabled by cortical function. Thus mattering to a subject in the way 
that provokes our moral concern goes beyond a reflex responsiveness 
and is tied to substantial cortical integrity. Therefore, where the 
neocortex is destroyed or permanently nonfunctional, our rational 
moral commitment to preserving life can be withdrawn in the case 
of an individual who has suffered this tragedy. The orienting, reflexive 
and vegetative responses that remain do not constitute mattering 
because there is neither a way in which they matter nor a reason why 
they matter to the human being in~olved.’~ That human being does 
not and cannot have thoughts or conscious experience because it lacks zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA

35 ‘Fiddling and clarity’ Journal zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBA.f Medical Ethic$ 13, 1987. Both the area of 
unrelativised things that matter and default or unavowedunavowable interests need 
a great deal more attention than my feeble gestures toward them might suggest. 

36 Art Caplan remarked at this point that it was unclear just what experiences 
would be had by a human being with an intact limbic system and brain stem. The 
initial temptation is to liken these to the conscious experiences of an animal with 
a brain structure showing only those features but even this would be misleading 
because such an animal does not need a cortex to evince the behaviour and sensitivity 
it shows whereas a human subject clearly does. A human limbic system cut off from 
cortical input is rendered defunctional. 



198 zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGRANT zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAGILLETT 

the functions constitutive of such e~perience.~’ This entails that a 
PVS patient cannot be benefited in any morally relevant sense and 
thus that decisions cannot be justified on that basis. At a stroke this 
undercuts many confused and emotive arguments in medical ethics. 

9. CONCLUSION 
I have argued that a person exists as a continuing subject of 
consciousness in view of being the subject of a complex of cognitive 
abilities. I have considered and dismissed the view that a slogan like 
‘what-it-is-like-to-be’ could provide a usable or perspicuous analysis 
of consciousness. The nature of the cognitive capacities constitutive 
of consciousness makes an individual a being to whom things matter 
or ‘a locus of ethical value’. These features of a person’s existence 
are dependent upon a certain complexity of appreciation of experience 
and that is why our ethical concern is undermined where extensive 
neurological damage has irrevocably obliterated her nature zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAas a subject 
of consciousness. The present analysis justifies certain ethical decisions 
about patients in the neurological states concerned in a way that is 
immune from persistent sceptical problems about the presence or 
absence of consciousness. 

37 The fact that things do not matter to the individual involved should not, 
without further argument, be taken to indicate that what we do to them does not 
matter at all; think, for instance, of insults to a person visited on his zyxwvutsrqponmlkjihgfedcbaZYXWVUTSRQPONMLKJIHGFEDCBAcorpse or the 
normal duty to observe the terms of a person’s will.
content.title: Consciousness_the_Brain_and_What_Matters.pdf

O artigo "Consciousness, The Brain and What Matters", de Grant Gillett, discute a relação entre consciência, funcionamento cerebral e considerações éticas. Aqui estão alguns dos principais pontos abordados:

1. **A centralidade da consciência na ética** – A presença ou ausência de consciência influencia nossas decisões morais, especialmente em casos de lesões cerebrais irreversíveis. A ideia é que, se um indivíduo perde permanentemente a capacidade de ter experiências conscientes, isso afeta sua identidade pessoal e sua consideração ética.

2. **O problema da definição de consciência** – Gillett explora a ideia de Thomas Nagel de que a consciência é definida pelo "o que é ser" um determinado ser. No entanto, ele argumenta que essa visão é insuficiente como uma análise formal da consciência.

3. **A neurologia da consciência** – O artigo discute o uso da Escala de Coma de Glasgow (GCS) para avaliar o nível de consciência de um paciente e descreve o papel do córtex cerebral e do sistema ativador reticular na sustentação da experiência consciente.

4. **Diferença entre estados cerebrais** – São exploradas diferenças entre estados como:
   - O estado vegetativo persistente (PVS), em que o cérebro perde funções cognitivas superiores enquanto mantém funções básicas, como respiração e reflexos.
   - A síndrome do encarceramento (Locked-in Syndrome), em que o indivíduo está consciente, mas incapaz de se mover ou se comunicar exceto por pequenos sinais.

5. **Crítica ao modelo cartesiano** – Gillett rejeita a visão de que a consciência é um estado puramente interno acessível apenas à introspecção. Ele defende uma abordagem mais comportamental e funcional, baseada na interação com o ambiente.

6. **Relação entre consciência e moralidade** – A consciência é associada à capacidade de se importar com coisas e tomar decisões baseadas em experiências passadas e raciocínio. O autor argumenta que, para algo "importar" moralmente, deve haver uma base consciente para experiências e preferências.

7. **Implicações éticas** – A partir dessa análise, Gillett argumenta que pacientes em estado vegetativo persistente, que perderam irreversivelmente a função cortical, não são mais sujeitos de experiências conscientes e, portanto, não podem ser beneficiados ou prejudicados da mesma forma que indivíduos conscientes.

O artigo busca integrar filosofia da mente, neurociência e ética médica para fundamentar decisões sobre vida e morte em casos de danos cerebrais severos.

Se quiser discutir algum trecho específico ou aprofundar algum aspecto, me avise!
o escritor gurdief fez trabalhos relacionados  à consciência ?

Sim, **George Ivanovich Gurdjieff** (c. 1866–1949) dedicou grande parte de sua obra ao estudo da **consciência** e da **transformação interior do ser humano**. Embora não tenha usado a linguagem acadêmica das neurociências ou da filosofia analítica como Grant Gillett, Gurdjieff foi profundamente influente em círculos espirituais e esotéricos, propondo um **sistema prático de autoconhecimento** voltado para o "despertar da consciência".

### As ideias de Gurdjieff sobre consciência:

1. **O homem vive em "sono"**  
   Gurdjieff afirmava que o ser humano comum vive em estado de **automatismo**, uma espécie de "sono desperto", em que as ações, pensamentos e emoções ocorrem de forma mecânica. Ele dizia:  
   > "O homem não lembra de si mesmo."

2. **A verdadeira consciência é rara**  
   Para Gurdjieff, **a consciência verdadeira — a capacidade de presença e percepção ativa — não é algo natural**, mas sim uma conquista. A maior parte das pessoas vive sem consciência real de seus atos ou pensamentos.

3. **Quatro estados de consciência**  
   Ele distinguia quatro níveis:
   - **Sono fisiológico**
   - **Estado de vigília comum** (que ele também considerava uma forma de sono)
   - **Autoconsciência** (estar consciente de si)
   - **Consciência objetiva** (estar consciente da realidade como ela é)

4. **O "Trabalho sobre si"**  
   Gurdjieff propôs um caminho para o desenvolvimento da consciência através do que ele chamava de "Trabalho" — práticas de atenção, presença, observação de si e exercícios físicos e mentais, com o objetivo de unificar o ser e despertar sua essência.

5. **O homem como máquina**  
   Ele usava a imagem do homem como uma máquina controlada por influências externas, até que esse homem aprenda a "lembrar de si" e a agir com **intenção consciente**.

6. **Consciência e moralidade**  
   Embora de forma diferente da abordagem de Gillett, Gurdjieff também considerava que **a verdadeira moralidade só poderia surgir de um ser verdadeiramente consciente** — ou seja, aquele que não reage mecanicamente, mas que percebe e escolhe.

## **Gurdjieff e a Consciência: aproximações preliminares com o pensamento de Grant Gillett**

### 1. Introdução

A consciência é tema central em diversas tradições filosóficas, científicas e espirituais. Este estudo propõe uma aproximação introdutória entre dois autores que tratam da consciência sob perspectivas distintas: o filósofo e neurocientista **Grant Gillett** e o pensador armênio **George Ivanovich Gurdjieff**. O objetivo é contextualizar Gurdjieff e destacar possíveis paralelos com o artigo “**Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters**” (1990), de Gillett, visando avaliar a pertinência de um aprofundamento acadêmico no tema.

---

### 2. Gurdjieff: autor, contexto e obra

**George Ivanovich Gurdjieff** (c. 1866–1949) foi um pensador de origem armênia-georgiana que desenvolveu um sistema de autoconhecimento conhecido como **"O Quarto Caminho"**, voltado ao desenvolvimento simultâneo do corpo, emoções e mente (OUSPENSKY, 2004). Estabelecido na França após a Primeira Guerra Mundial, fundou o Instituto para o Desenvolvimento Harmônico do Homem. Seu sistema propõe práticas de atenção e autopercepção que visam o despertar da consciência, especialmente por meio da técnica de *lembrança de si* (self-remembering) (GURDJIEFF, 2007).

Dentre suas obras destacam-se:
- *Relatos de Belzebu a seu Neto* (1950),
- *A Vida é Real Somente Quando “Eu Sou”* (1975),
- e *Encontros com Homens Notáveis* (2007), que, embora mais autobiográfica, oferece uma introdução ao seu percurso interior e visão de mundo.

---

### 3. A consciência em Gurdjieff

Para Gurdjieff, a consciência ordinária do ser humano é incompleta. A maioria das pessoas vive num estado de “sono psíquico”, respondendo mecanicamente ao ambiente. A verdadeira consciência, segundo o autor, requer esforço deliberado e prática contínua de atenção dividida e lembrança de si (GURDJIEFF, 1975). A consciência é, portanto, uma conquista e não uma condição inata ou automática.

---

### 4. Comparação com Grant Gillett

No artigo *"Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters"*, Gillett (1990) defende que a consciência é um conjunto de capacidades cognitivas manifestas, sensíveis ao ambiente, articuladas com linguagem e conceito de pessoa. Para ele, a ausência de consciência — especialmente em casos de dano neurológico irreversível — implica a perda de valor moral do indivíduo.

Apesar das abordagens distintas, há **convergências conceituais**:
- Ambos os autores consideram a **manifestação da consciência** como critério para atribuição de valor ao ser humano.
- Gurdjieff aborda a ausência de consciência como **perda da essência do ser**; Gillett, como perda da condição de pessoa.
- Em Gillett, o suporte da consciência é o córtex cerebral; em Gurdjieff, a consciência é uma função superior do ser que precisa ser construída com esforço.

---

### 5. Considerações finais

A aproximação entre Gurdjieff e Gillett sugere uma interseção entre neurofilosofia e tradição esotérica que pode enriquecer o debate sobre o valor moral da consciência. A continuidade deste estudo poderá incluir a análise aprofundada das obras principais de Gurdjieff, bem como uma releitura crítica do artigo de Gillett à luz de conceitos como *self-remembering* e *trabalho sobre si*. Trata-se, portanto, de uma proposta exploratória, com potencial interdisciplinar entre filosofia da mente, neurociência e estudos da consciência.

---

Essa fragmentação se **acentua em ambientes coletivos**, como multidões ou manifestações emocionais de grupo.

**Trecho relacionado**:
> “O homem é uma máquina. Tudo o que ele faz, ele faz automaticamente. Em si mesmo, ele não tem nenhuma unidade. O homem não se lembra de si. (...) Em uma multidão, o homem se perde completamente, sua individualidade desaparece.”  
(*OUSPENSKY, 2004, p. 66-68*, tradução livre)

O próprio Gurdjieff alerta que, sob forte influência emocional de grupos (como uma torcida ou festa), o indivíduo **é arrastado por impulsos coletivos** e perde a capacidade de “lembrar-se de si”. Esse estado seria o oposto da prática do “trabalho sobre si”, que requer vigilância interior constante.

---

### 🎨 Desenvolvimento da ilustração conceitual:

**Conceito visual:**  
> Um indivíduo está no meio de uma multidão vibrante — por exemplo, **uma torcida de futebol em êxtase**, ou **um bloco de carnaval dançante**.  
> Todos gritam, pulam, gesticulam.  
> O indivíduo, porém, está ligeiramente deslocado do fluxo: **os olhos não seguem os outros, mas olham para dentro ou fixam-se em algo diferente**.  
> Enquanto os outros se dissolvem na massa, **ele parece tentar “lembrar de si”**.  
> A multidão é mostrada em traços confusos, enquanto **ele está desenhado com traços mais nítidos, quase iluminado**.

**Elementos simbólicos possíveis:**
- A multidão pode estar sombreada ou nebulosa.
- O indivíduo pode ter um reflexo que mostra duas versões: a que grita e a que observa silenciosamente.
- Cores mais frias para ele; cores vibrantes e caóticas para o grupo.

content.text:
from fpdf import FPDF
from PIL import Image

# Caminho da imagem selecionada (segunda imagem)
image_path = "/mnt/data/A_symbolic_digital_painting_showing_a_calm_individ.png"

# Criar PDF
pdf = FPDF()
pdf.add_page()
pdf.set_auto_page_break(auto=True, margin=15)

# Título
pdf.set_font("Arial", 'B', 16)
pdf.cell(0, 10, "Gurdjieff e a Consciência: aproximações preliminares com Grant Gillett", ln=True, align='C')

# Espaço
pdf.ln(10)

# Inserir imagem
image = Image.open(image_path)
image_width, image_height = image.size
aspect_ratio = image_height / image_width
pdf_width = 180
pdf_height = pdf_width * aspect_ratio
pdf.image(image_path, x=15, y=30, w=pdf_width)
pdf.ln(int(pdf_height) + 10)

# Texto completo (resumido e formal, com explicação da imagem)
text = """
Esta imagem ilustra um insight baseado nos ensinamentos de Gurdjieff: a perda da consciência de si em situações de envolvimento coletivo intenso, como em festas ou torcidas. Segundo Gurdjieff, o ser humano vive em estado de “sono psíquico”, e em multidões essa condição se acentua, pois o indivíduo tende a agir mecanicamente conforme o grupo, perdendo sua individualidade e presença interior.

Na imagem, vemos um indivíduo calmo e consciente no centro de uma multidão caótica e vibrante. A multidão expressa energia emocional coletiva, enquanto o indivíduo está sereno e com traços definidos, simbolizando o “lembrar de si” – uma prática central no sistema de Gurdjieff.

Este trabalho propõe uma introdução à vida e obra de Gurdjieff, destacando sua abordagem sobre a consciência como conquista interior, e em seguida, traça paralelos com o artigo “Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters” (1990), de Grant Gillett, no qual a consciência também figura como critério de valor moral e identidade pessoal. A comparação sugere uma convergência entre abordagens esotéricas e neurofilosóficas, justificando o aprofundamento do tema em estudo futuro.

Referências:

GILLETT, Grant. Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters. Philosophical Psychology, v. 4, n. 3, 1990.

GURDJIEFF, G. I. Encontros com Homens Notáveis. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2007.

GURDJIEFF, G. I. A vida é real somente quando “Eu Sou”. São Paulo: Pensamento, 1975.

OUSPENSKY, P. D. Em busca do milagroso: fragmentos de um ensinamento desconhecido. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2004.
"""

pdf.set_font("Arial", '', 12)
pdf.multi_cell(0, 10, text)

# Salvar PDF
pdf_output_path = "/mnt/data/Gurdjieff_e_a_Consciência_com_imagem.pdf"
pdf.output(pdf_output_path)

pdf_output_path

Claro, Marcos! Aqui está uma versão resumida com linguagem acadêmica formal, estruturada para uma apresentação introdutória ao professor Walter Chesnut, seguindo as normas da ABNT para citações e referências:

⸻

Gurdjieff e a Consciência: aproximações preliminares com o pensamento de Grant Gillett

1. Introdução

A consciência é tema central em diversas tradições filosóficas, científicas e espirituais. Este estudo propõe uma aproximação introdutória entre dois autores que tratam da consciência sob perspectivas distintas: o filósofo e neurocientista Grant Gillett e o pensador armênio George Ivanovich Gurdjieff. O objetivo é contextualizar Gurdjieff e destacar possíveis paralelos com o artigo “Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters” (1990), de Gillett, visando avaliar a pertinência de um aprofundamento acadêmico no tema.

⸻

2. Gurdjieff: autor, contexto e obra

George Ivanovich Gurdjieff (c. 1866–1949) foi um pensador de origem armênia-georgiana que desenvolveu um sistema de autoconhecimento conhecido como “O Quarto Caminho”, voltado ao desenvolvimento simultâneo do corpo, emoções e mente (OUSPENSKY, 2004). Estabelecido na França após a Primeira Guerra Mundial, fundou o Instituto para o Desenvolvimento Harmônico do Homem. Seu sistema propõe práticas de atenção e autopercepção que visam o despertar da consciência, especialmente por meio da técnica de lembrança de si (self-remembering) (GURDJIEFF, 2007).

Dentre suas obras destacam-se:
	•	Relatos de Belzebu a seu Neto (1950),
	•	A Vida é Real Somente Quando “Eu Sou” (1975),
	•	e Encontros com Homens Notáveis (2007), que, embora mais autobiográfica, oferece uma introdução ao seu percurso interior e visão de mundo.

⸻

3. A consciência em Gurdjieff

Para Gurdjieff, a consciência ordinária do ser humano é incompleta. A maioria das pessoas vive num estado de “sono psíquico”, respondendo mecanicamente ao ambiente. A verdadeira consciência, segundo o autor, requer esforço deliberado e prática contínua de atenção dividida e lembrança de si (GURDJIEFF, 1975). A consciência é, portanto, uma conquista e não uma condição inata ou automática.

⸻

4. Comparação com Grant Gillett

No artigo “Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters”, Gillett (1990) defende que a consciência é um conjunto de capacidades cognitivas manifestas, sensíveis ao ambiente, articuladas com linguagem e conceito de pessoa. Para ele, a ausência de consciência — especialmente em casos de dano neurológico irreversível — implica a perda de valor moral do indivíduo.

Apesar das abordagens distintas, há convergências conceituais:
	•	Ambos os autores consideram a manifestação da consciência como critério para atribuição de valor ao ser humano.
	•	Gurdjieff aborda a ausência de consciência como perda da essência do ser; Gillett, como perda da condição de pessoa.
	•	Em Gillett, o suporte da consciência é o córtex cerebral; em Gurdjieff, a consciência é uma função superior do ser que precisa ser construída com esforço.

⸻

5. Considerações finais

A aproximação entre Gurdjieff e Gillett sugere uma interseção entre neurofilosofia e tradição esotérica que pode enriquecer o debate sobre o valor moral da consciência. A continuidade deste estudo poderá incluir a análise aprofundada das obras principais de Gurdjieff, bem como uma releitura crítica do artigo de Gillett à luz de conceitos como self-remembering e trabalho sobre si. Trata-se, portanto, de uma proposta exploratória, com potencial interdisciplinar entre filosofia da mente, neurociência e estudos da consciência.

⸻

Referências (ABNT)

GILLETT, Grant. Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters. Philosophical Psychology, v. 4, n. 3, 1990.

GURDJIEFF, G. I. Encontros com Homens Notáveis. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2007.

GURDJIEFF, G. I. A vida é real somente quando “Eu Sou”. São Paulo: Pensamento, 1975.

OUSPENSKY, P. D. Em busca do milagroso: fragmentos de um ensinamento desconhecido. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2004.

⸻

content.text:
# Salvar o conteúdo final em formato Markdown (.md)
markdown_text = """# Gurdjieff e a Consciência: aproximações preliminares com o pensamento de Grant Gillett

## 1. Introdução

A consciência é tema central em diversas tradições filosóficas, científicas e espirituais. Este estudo propõe uma aproximação introdutória entre dois autores que tratam da consciência sob perspectivas distintas: o filósofo e neurocientista Grant Gillett e o pensador armênio George Ivanovich Gurdjieff. O objetivo é contextualizar Gurdjieff e destacar possíveis paralelos com o artigo “Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters” (1990), de Gillett, visando avaliar a pertinência de um aprofundamento acadêmico no tema.

---

## 2. Gurdjieff: autor, contexto e obra

George Ivanovich Gurdjieff (c. 1866–1949) foi um pensador de origem armênia-georgiana que desenvolveu um sistema de autoconhecimento conhecido como “O Quarto Caminho”, voltado ao desenvolvimento simultâneo do corpo, emoções e mente (OUSPENSKY, 2004). Estabelecido na França após a Primeira Guerra Mundial, fundou o Instituto para o Desenvolvimento Harmônico do Homem. Seu sistema propõe práticas de atenção e autopercepção que visam o despertar da consciência, especialmente por meio da técnica de lembrança de si (*self-remembering*) (GURDJIEFF, 2007).

Dentre suas obras destacam-se:
- *Relatos de Belzebu a seu Neto* (1950),
- *A Vida é Real Somente Quando “Eu Sou”* (1975),
- *Encontros com Homens Notáveis* (2007), que, embora mais autobiográfica, oferece uma introdução ao seu percurso interior e visão de mundo.

---

## 3. A consciência em Gurdjieff

Para Gurdjieff, a consciência ordinária do ser humano é incompleta. A maioria das pessoas vive num estado de “sono psíquico”, respondendo mecanicamente ao ambiente. A verdadeira consciência, segundo o autor, requer esforço deliberado e prática contínua de atenção dividida e lembrança de si (GURDJIEFF, 1975). A consciência é, portanto, uma conquista e não uma condição inata ou automática.

---

## 4. Comparação com Grant Gillett

No artigo *“Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters”*, Gillett (1990) defende que a consciência é um conjunto de capacidades cognitivas manifestas, sensíveis ao ambiente, articuladas com linguagem e conceito de pessoa. Para ele, a ausência de consciência — especialmente em casos de dano neurológico irreversível — implica a perda de valor moral do indivíduo.

Apesar das abordagens distintas, há convergências conceituais:
- Ambos os autores consideram a manifestação da consciência como critério para atribuição de valor ao ser humano;
- Gurdjieff aborda a ausência de consciência como perda da essência do ser; Gillett, como perda da condição de pessoa;
- Em Gillett, o suporte da consciência é o córtex cerebral; em Gurdjieff, a consciência é uma função superior do ser que precisa ser construída com esforço.

---

## 5. Considerações finais

A aproximação entre Gurdjieff e Gillett sugere uma interseção entre neurofilosofia e tradição esotérica que pode enriquecer o debate sobre o valor moral da consciência. A continuidade deste estudo poderá incluir a análise aprofundada das obras principais de Gurdjieff, bem como uma releitura crítica do artigo de Gillett à luz de conceitos como *self-remembering* e *trabalho sobre si*. Trata-se, portanto, de uma proposta exploratória, com potencial interdisciplinar entre filosofia da mente, neurociência e estudos da consciência.

---

## Referências (ABNT)

GILLETT, Grant. *Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters*. Philosophical Psychology, v. 4, n. 3, 1990.  
GURDJIEFF, G. I. *Encontros com Homens Notáveis*. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2007.  
GURDJIEFF, G. I. *A vida é real somente quando “Eu Sou”*. São Paulo: Pensamento, 1975.  
OUSPENSKY, P. D. *Em busca do milagroso: fragmentos de um ensinamento desconhecido*. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2004.
"""

# Salvar o conteúdo em arquivo Markdown
md_path = "/mnt/data/Gurdjieff_e_Gillett.md"
with open(md_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(markdown_text)

md_path

content.text:
# Tradução do conteúdo para o inglês
markdown_text_en = """# Gurdjieff and Consciousness: Preliminary Approaches in Dialogue with Grant Gillett's Thought

## 1. Introduction

Consciousness is a central theme in various philosophical, scientific, and spiritual traditions. This study proposes an introductory approach between two authors who deal with consciousness from distinct perspectives: the philosopher and neuroscientist Grant Gillett and the Armenian thinker George Ivanovich Gurdjieff. The objective is to contextualize Gurdjieff and highlight possible parallels with the article “Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters” (1990) by Gillett, aiming to assess the relevance ...

---

## 2. Gurdjieff: Author, Context, and Work

George Ivanovich Gurdjieff (c. 1866–1949) was a thinker of Armenian-Georgian origin who developed a self-knowledge system known as “The Fourth Way,” aimed at the simultaneous development of the body, emotions, and mind (OUSPENSKY, 2004). Settled in France after World War I, he founded the Institute for the Harmonious Development of Man. His system proposes practices of attention and self-observation aimed at awakening consciousness, especially through the technique of self-remembering (GURDJIEFF, 2007).

Among his main works are:
- *Beelzebub's Tales to His Grandson* (1950),
- *Life is Real Only Then, When “I Am”* (1975),
- and *Meetings with Remarkable Men* (2007), which, although more autobiographical, offers an introduction to his inner path and worldview.

---

## 3. Consciousness in Gurdjieff

For Gurdjieff, the ordinary consciousness of the human being is incomplete. Most people live in a state of "psychic sleep," reacting mechanically to their environment. True consciousness, according to the author, requires deliberate effort and continuous practice of divided attention and self-remembering (GURDJIEFF, 1975). Consciousness is, therefore, an achievement rather than an innate or automatic condition.

---

## 4. Comparison with Grant Gillett

In the article *“Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters”*, Gillett (1990) argues that consciousness is a set of manifest cognitive capacities, responsive to the environment, articulated with language and the concept of personhood. For him, the absence of consciousness—especially in cases of irreversible neurological damage—implies the loss of the individual's moral value.

Despite the distinct approaches, there are conceptual convergences:
- Both authors consider the manifestation of consciousness as a criterion for assigning value to the human being;
- Gurdjieff addresses the absence of consciousness as the loss of the essence of being; Gillett, as the loss of the condition of personhood;
- In Gillett, the support of consciousness is the cerebral cortex; in Gurdjieff, consciousness is a higher function of being that must be developed through effort.

---

## 5. Final Considerations

The approximation between Gurdjieff and Gillett suggests an intersection between neurophilosophy and esoteric tradition that can enrich the debate on the moral value of consciousness. The continuity of this study may include an in-depth analysis of Gurdjieff's main works, as well as a critical rereading of Gillett’s article in light of concepts such as self-remembering and inner work. It is, therefore, an exploratory proposal with interdisciplinary potential among philosophy of mind, neuroscience, and conscio...

---

## References (ABNT Style)

GILLETT, Grant. *Consciousness, the Brain and What Matters*. Philosophical Psychology, v. 4, n. 3, 1990.  
GURDJIEFF, G. I. *Meetings with Remarkable Men*. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2007.  
GURDJIEFF, G. I. *Life is Real Only Then, When “I Am”*. São Paulo: Pensamento, 1975.  
OUSPENSKY, P. D. *In Search of the Miraculous: Fragments of an Unknown Teaching*. São Paulo: Pensamento, 2004.
"""

# Salvar o conteúdo em arquivo Markdown traduzido
md_en_path = "/mnt/data/Gurdjieff_and_Gillett.md"
with open(md_en_path, "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    f.write(markdown_text_en)

md_en_path
